escort missions are NOT fun, and there are way too many in this game.
If you want to PLAY this game get the INFINITY version, that way you won't have to endure almost an entire campaign of annoying escort missions.
Amazing fun! Love this game. If you like space combat flight games get this.

Once I got used to the controls (I used Keyboard & Mouse), it was actually a pretty good game.  The combat was intense and using the strike suit to obliterate entire formations was a lot of fun.  They even managed to make the bomber not feel like a flying coffin, which is a major accomplishment in my book.  The only blight on otherwise excellent level design was the absoluteley terrible the final mission.  I don't know why devs keep putting flying through tunnels" missions in games about shooting things in space.  With that said
date: if you enjoy arcade style shooters like Star Fox and Rogue Squadron this is definitely worth checking out."

reviewText: very fun game !!!

Great game, great atmosphere. Yes, it is shooting at things the whole time, but add the environments and all that and you have a perfectly good game. I would recommend getting it for the weekend deal so you do not have to spend $20.

Gundam and Freelancer had a baby: it's a monster. Absolutely brutal. But so much fun. The controls seemed a little sluggish on a mouse and keyboard, but I found a good joystick made things much more intuitive. It may get frustrating sometimes having to redo things when you die, but if you can get into it and do well, it's a real blast to play.
Very empty generic repatative space shooter. I got bored fast.
The shooting takes a bit to get used to but it is a fun game.
YUS

I did not recommend this game for a few reasons:

First reason: No multiplayer. I think this game, with tweaking, could be good for multiplayer, but that doesn't seem to be on the horizon yet. However, if you're more of a single-player type person, this point need not apply to you.

Second reason: Does not offer a demo. At least what I could find. This game, at the time of this writing, is on sale %75, and I bought the entire Strike Suit Zero Mega Bundle for $9.99. However, that's ten bucks I could have saved had I tried a demo first.

Third reason: Not what I thought it was going to be like. Let me elaborate on this a little. First, it was my clumsy fault that I didn't notice that this game didn't support multiplayer. Some of you may remember playing a little Microsoft Studios game called Freelancer, which was an amazing spaceflight game. If you're looking for a game like that, this isn't it. I completed the first mission, and sadly to say I got kinda bored; too bored in fact to finish the second mission.

Overall, the game and its graphics are nice. I wish I had a nicer graphics card to take advantage of the wonderful effects I could see in the trailers. However, the gameplay is very repetitive with little reward.
awesome!
This game is difficult at first but can be lots of fun once you get the hang of it.
almost like playing freelancer again :D
Good game, can be hard at time. Controls are tight even if its hard.
Good game for the Oculus Rift. but you can tell it wasn't made for it.
Personally, I didn't like it. Way too difficult right from the beginning, can't see much variety in gameplay at all yet, although I'm not far in due to difficulty

A really well made indie game.  The graphics and gamplay mechanics are increadible, and the special strike mode of the Strike Suit(While limited) makes you feel like death incarnate.  And the weapons are truely balanced.  Better, more powerful weapons have less ammount of charge or supply.  And the scale of the second to last level is amasing.  250+ enemies fighters, a horde of friendly fighters, and scores of large starships.  And with those graphics, I didn't even lose frame rate on my simple, 11 inch Macbook Air.

One of the most pleasurable arcadde style flight sims that I have played in years. If you are in search of fast based action with loads of replayability then look no further. The controls are tight and the missionns offer a good variety of challenges. For a real tough time, pick up the Heroes of the Fleet DLC.

Do you like escort missions? No? Well tough. The game starts out quite well, with tight responsive controls and frankly great looking graphics, but the repetetive mission structure tends to get in the way of my enjoyment. Every mission I have played so far has at least one escort section and due to this the variety feels somewhat limited.

This game falls into the ''criminally underrated'' category. Remember when IGN gave Godhand a 3 when everyone else gave it a 7 or 8? It's kinda like that. I'm not gonna spend too much time on this, but the reviewers that gave it a low score did so because they are inept at playing anything harder than Mario. ''It's too hard'' was the MAIN complaint, and it's pathetic because it's not.

Anyway, think Star Fox 64's 'all-range mode', but with a lot more enemies. You get 13 missions with an unfolding plot, and upgrades along the way that are unlocked by completing optional objectives that present some difficulty, but hardly the difficulty the ♥♥♥♥♥-♥♥♥ reviewers say it posseses. You're given objectives in the middle of the mission, but it boils down to killing ♥♥♥♥ and blowing up big ships. Each mission varies up the scenario to avoid repetetiveness: protecting a fleet, taking out a ship in particular (or protecting it), taking out incoming torpedos, loss of missile systems.

Just a tip: press the camera button (default is 'C') to go into first person. You have to do this for both your fighter and the Strike Suit, otherwise you're in first person in fighter mode and third person in Strike mode. It makes the fighting a lot more intense and increases that sense of inertia.

Incredibly fun; highly recommended; intense dogfighting on dogfighting action; buy it now.

Fan of Space combat simulators?  Fan of the old 'X-wing' or 'Rogue Squadron' game series?  Love the classic anime titles such as Robotech and/or Super Dimension Fortress Macross?  This game will meet all those needs and more.  I'm not quite done with the game yet personally, but so far I'm loving every second of it.\n\nThe controls might need a little work, and the compatibility with existing controllers could be a little nicer and automatic instead of painfully testing each button.  But if you only play with Keyboard, then none of that will be a problem for you.

This game is really great. It has all the features of space combat simulation, and adds an extra gameplay improvement with the Strike Suit's strike mode.

Pursuit mode is dynamic both when you're against fighters and capital ships (the big ships). The targeting system is very efficient and allows you to easily spot the best target. Strike mode adds a new gameplay with a different (and more interesting) movement control (especially efficient against capital ships) and deadly weapons very useful against fighters.

The thirteen missions have a wide variety of objectives which make every one feel unique, and the improvement of both your ship and your pilot's abilities give it a high level of replayability.

Even better with a joystick, in first person view.
Got this for oculus rift support - but its basically unplayable and the dev seems to have abandoned support for the game
love this game...wish it were more like it

The game didn't leave a good impression on me early in, but I stuck through it until mission 12 hoping for it to grab me, and now I'm done with it.  The game just isn't well designed, and mission 12 fully expressed that to me.  The weapons you get are limited in selection throughout the level.  The objectives and things you do rarely change and deviate from a formula they repeat every other level or 2.  It's basically defend X, attack X, or attack turrets on X to then get to attack X afterwards.

Worse yet is on larger vehicles you're supposed to destroy you get little in terms of visual or auditory feedback that you're actually doing decent damage yourself, or if it's just your friendly ally ships.  When the objectives change, the game will do a poor job explaining what you actualy need to do, and point out targets that don't remotely matter to actually finishing it.

The game just does nothing remarkeable outside your strike suite can lock on, and let you paint multiple targets to fire a large missile barrage.  Fun for the first few times, but quickly becomes a tedious activity, as you'll use it a bunch to ween down health on ships with inflated HP.

This game is incredible. The graphics are absolutely beautiful, the combat is fun and challenging, and the feeling of manuevering the three dimesional space while avoiding missiles and ships is exhilerating. 10/10
Very good! The menus are confusing, but the game is pure fun, like the old Star Wars space games.

I love this game!  The controls are a little strange to get used to, but the progression of difficulty through levels is great for getting the hang of the game.  This also allows great replay value for you to go back to earlier levels and clean the floor with the enemies that gave you trouble early on for a higher score.\n\nGreat soundtrack, great look, great feel.  A really great game.
A great game that is challenging and interesing!\n\n8/10
Neautiful graphics, streamlined controls, awesome space combat sim. Bad ♥♥♥ game.
fun flight sim with good effects and space mechs! the tracers behind the ships and the graphic are nice, it get tough in those last levels but its fun to fight an entire fleet and win.

No regrets picking this up (on sale at least).\nPros: amazing soundtrack, nice variety of ships, enjoyable gameplay, good challenges and length of missions, ecstatic immersive pew pew space combat. Missions are fun enough to re-do on higher difficulty and once unlocked you can use different ships when going back to replay missions.\nCons: Lack of customization in ships (you can make a couple choices in weapon loadouts but all other upgrades are tied to nailing mission achievements and don't come with options), targetting itself works well once you get past the learning curve but switching target priorities could be done a little more intuitively, story is so-so - decent enough in a generic way to move you on to more pew pew goodness.

reviewText: The controls made me sad. Rest of the game was ok though.

Luckily I bought this game after they fixed all the major issues, so no complaint there. Game works fine for me.
I've played this game the whole way through, and I can safely say I had an absolute blast. The combat was fun and fast paced, the ship designs were neat, though definitely more variety was a must there, yet overall the game had a very stylized look and feel to it. Plus the music was pretty damn bad ♥♥♥ as well. The fighting in the game seems so visceral, I love it in games where your the queen in a very large chess game. Also, the strike suit itself is pretty damn cool, shooting out tons of missles a la macross.
Although I must admit, the controls are pretty wonky. Not being able to flip around or do a quick 360 or anything like that is pretty annoying, not to mention the overall awkward control scheme you need to get used to. Voice acting and story is also pretty mediocre, could've used definite improvements there. Also, the missions get pretty repetitive, and the ones where you have to blow up specific buildings or such, with no fast way to turn around it really gets annoying fast.
Overall though, if you like fast action space combat games, this is one you should definitely get.
Fun so far

While this isn't a bad game it sure ain't a great one.  Probably my biggest complaint of this game is the gameplay.  It just felt like a slightly improved Battlefront 2 space battles.  Probably the only cool component of gameplay was the Strike Suit (which you dont even get until a hour in).  Another thing that ruined the game for me was the missions.  They were way too long and generic.  It was go kill these invaders...oh look more of them go kill them too.  The story to go along with it was alright but nothing too special.  The graphics were great for an indie game.  The ship graphics were okay, but the backgrounds (space and planets) were awesome.  Probably the best thing about this game was the soundtrack.  I usually don't even think about the soundtrack when playing games but this one was different, its amazing. Too bad the game wasn't on par with the soundtrack.
Sweet Gundam Type Space ACTION GAME very fast Gameplay Enjoyed 100% THUMBS UPP!!
Great game! Only misses a Star Wars mod with X-Wings and TIE-Fighters :)
Amazing space combat sim game!

It's a cute anime style space shootem-up. I was expecting something more akin to conflict freespace, so I was a bit disapponted. All in all, I find the game frustrating because it's hard to tell where you need to be, something that they could easily solve with an in-game radar, like in any other spacy shootem-up.

Even though I still haven't finished the first campaign, I still heavily recommend this to any sci-fi fan who likes anime or space sims. I have enjoyed this game so much since it was the first game since Freelancer in a space setting that I played. 8/10 Because it could be longer, and maybe a little more versatility. Other than that, I love this game.

This game is really, REALLY good! I have seen reviews that knock the storyline, but it's an action/arcade style space shooter, not a storyline game, and it delivers PERFECTLY on what it tries to be.\n\nHighly Recommended!!!
If you like Freespace 2 this is ... not the same but has similar feeling in many ways. Definitely more gamey than simulator but still great.

Definitely satisfied a Macross itch that needed to be stratched. Fire dozens of swarm missles at rebellious colonists as a mech. Fly around large capital ships. Chase down enemy fighters in dogfights. It is all there!\nHowever, the checkpoints within the levels are quite spaced out and I found myself playing some sections multiple times, especially during escort missions. My HVT would go half to zero health in a mater of seconds, which could be quite frustrating. There are 4 types of ships, although the strike suit" was the most enjoyable. I felt that the customization was lacking and would have liked to see more variety than level 1
recommended: level 3 of the same three weapons. The story is decent for a short game and was enough to keep me going level to level. Definitely worth a playthrough."

An awesome space combat game. Think of it like Macross the video game. Combat is challenging, but fun and very flashy. Game starts off a bit slow, but picks up after mission 3 once you get the Strike Suit. The game can spike in difficulty very randomly, but never to the point of impossibility. The only thing I would hold against it is the bonus upgrades. Some of them ask you to complete a secondary objective of some sort. However, many of these objectives go against actually doing well on the mission. Very often, when I replayed the mission to get the secondary objective, I ended up doing far worse rating wise then I did just playing the mission normally.\n\nAll in all, a fantastic dog-fighting, large-scale, space combat game and well worth the price of $20. Even better when it's on sale.
So much more could be done with this game, I find Strike Suit Zero very fun.

reviewerDisplayName: The Roamer of The Bright Sea
reviewText: This game, is awesome. Graphics 10/10. Gameplay 9/10 Story 8/10 Music 10/10. This game was beautifully created. Cheers to the creators. At first I thought that it looked Meh but once I bought it during the steam christmas sales, my thoughts did a full 180. I would have actually payed the whole price had I know how awesomely awesome this is. If you love space battles and hard battles, this game is for you. None of that casual bull that other space sims give you. This game thrusts you into the fray instantly and with out a single damn to give you. Perfect game, 9.9/10, would do again.

Well I really enjoyed that, the mouse and keyboard controls worked great and the combat was just the right difficulty. I really enjoyed switching targets and managing the priority of threats as they came up, as well as ensuring I was using the right weapons at the right times... it was a lot to think about whilst in the midst of a space war.. and I must admit it was really engaging. Got me very much in the mood for Freelancer, another game I have never finished, which has similar controls... ableit isn't involving huge capital ships blasting away at one another in an overarching space conflict like SSZ. The graphics and sound are perfect and it's a well put together game.

I can't credit it with originality though, the music seemed to be from Homeworld, the way the capital ships duked it out with huge laser beams streaking between them.. really felt like Freespace, the controls seemed to be taken from Freelancer like I've said, the unflappable naval officers seem to be ripped out of Nexus - The jupiter incident and the narrative.... inspired by them all I'd say.

Still! A good game and enjoyable, if they do a sequel I'd certainly keep an eye on it and pick it up at the right price.

The Heroes of the Fleet is an enjoyable DLC revolving around simulations of key battles, mainly one's that were historically defeats for the Earth forces you pilot for, all of which took place within the main story line however the protagonist wasn't part of them. . I liked the narrative twist and enjoyed the fact they'd even *put* a thread of story throughout 6 stand alone DLC missions. I think that's commendable.

These level's are hard and I found my self on the edge of my seat during the last level in particular, fun times.

Ignore the haters and naysayers, when was the last time we got a game like this? Yeah, that long. So just get this, fire away and lock-on targets to release endless streams of deadly missiles. That's how it rolls. Ignore the minimum specs, it can ran on weaker configurations but your mileage may vary. But, yeah, this is Omega Boost meets Freespace 2 with touches of Homeworld!
It's Rogue Squadron on steroids

Space shooter that is a surprising amount of fun.  Very challenging on later levels and has additional challenges for the difficulty obsessed.  I couldn't quite beat it before I lost interest, but definitely enjoyed the ride, great value for money.

If you're into space shooters, this is a ♥♥♥♥♥torm of awesomesauce!  The controls and the 360-degree style of flight sort of remind me of the levels in Star Wars: Shadows of the Empire (N64) where you pilot the Outrider - it wasn't what I was expecting at first, but it doesn't take long to get used to.\n\nPerformance-wise, I'm running this on a 4-year old computer with an Intel integrated graphics card and 4Gb of RAM.  Most of my games lag somewhat and use quite a lot of CPU, but I had SSZ on the highest graphic settings (which look amazing by the way), and there was no lag or drop in framerate at all!

Might've gotten poor reviews, but don't let that fool you! This be the best dang darn space combat simulator out there. It's beautiful, plenty of action, it's an indie game! If you didn't get enough epic space combat from this....they got DLC! and another game called Strike Suit Infinity! Fight off endless waves of enemy ships in an endless epic battle! WHOO!

Fun game, with an interesting combination feel of Freespace" and "Batman: Arkham Asylum".  The story is a little weak but they at least make some efforts to have a coherent one.  The combat system is quite engaging and you can easily beat most levels but doing so with flare and skill is quite a challenge.  Easy to learn
Not the greatest game of all time, but with the right music it's pretty good. 60 at metacritic is too low, maybe 75 would be good. Underrated.

date: and shoot'em up experience" to date. Respectable graphics

reviewText: Great change of pace.  Different from many other games out there.  Feels like a throw back to a Star Wars Rouge Squadron but a fresh new look and game mechanics.
Old school 6d space shooter + robots = amazing.  Controller recommended.
Slightly weird controls at first, but if you get used to them, the game is great. Haven't had this much fun in a space sim since Colony Wars.\n\nEdit: Seriously, pretty decent game.

Strike Suit Zero is a very unique game. It's offers a level of immersion that other space opera games lack. This is a heavy action-oriented game and the story is not merely a vehicle.  Controls are not complex and only several keys are required and the game doesn't dump a rediculous ammount on you, forcing you to stretch your hand all accross your keyboard. The plot is not pointless too. It will fool you into thinking it's a total linear story line. So SPOILER ALERT: at the very end you have a choice.

Combat is very satisfying. Ships are graceful, fair, and not clunky to handle. Controls are simple, easy to operate, and convenient. The story surprised me as stated above.

If you like mecha games such as armored core, military themed areial combat, space opera, then you will love this game and it's sequel Strike Suit Infinity.

If you're looking for a good space combat dog-fighting game then look no further. Strike Suit Zero is pretty, challenging, and fun. It also supports the Oculus Rift, if you happen to have one of those.\n\nI also highly recommend Strike Suit Infinity. Instead of following a campaign story you play a wave attack/survival mode where you can spend points to buy upgrades like allied fighters and boosts.

A beautiful space combat game with good controls and jaw dropping graphics. For less than half of a big budget title, you get a well polished work of art. It's not an advanced flight sim, so anybody can grasp the controls with KB&M!

PROS:
-Beautiful 3d and 2d graphics and artwork
-Amazing voice acting
-Compelling story
-Easy to learn controls
-Entrancing soundtrack (buy the OST!)

CONS:
-Short campaign with disappointing end level
-Modest arsenal of weapons

Definitely an awesome game and has great graphics to pair itself with. The storyline is a bit cheesy but it makes the game more fun. I really have enjoyed this game so far and currently trying to fight my way through the 5th level. I don't regret buying this at all and believe this is worth every penny I spent. I hope to see the makers of this game flourish and look forward to future titles. Buy this game if you like crazy dog fighting, good graphics, and a challenge.

Normally I can't get behind space based games...  This is definately one exception to my rule.  I especially like how well it plays on multiple different systems with the same control set and feel for the controls.  It really shows how well designed the game is.
Totalmente adictivo, me recordo tanto a macross :D
Badass visuals but controls are clunky.

This is one of the most satisfying games that I have ever played. I am a fan of mech anime and an even greater fan of Star Wars, so this game was everything that I could have ever hoped for. Gameplay-wise, the controls are smooth to the point where you wouldn't even know that this is an indie game. The missions are a pretty decent length, with action over at every moment. I can't say that I really feel for the characters, but that wasn't what I bought the game for. If you are hoping for story, do not come any further, However, if you are hoping for action packed, literally explosive awesomeness, come much further! The battles in this game are spectacular. Instead of just shoting the capital ships in any random spot, the game urges you to go for many of the weak points and weapons that bristle of each of them. As for graphics, this may not be The Last of Us, but the graphics are good enough to make for a beautiful game at every moment. The backgrounds are spectacular and gorgeous, with vibrant shades of colors, the best probably being the shades of purple and blue. When it comes to the soundtrack, Paul Ruskay and Kokia di an amazing job, with the ambiance of the game enhanced tenfold by the fastpaced songs. This game is definately worth the price, as well as the counterpart, Strike Suit Infinity.\n\nI have not bought a PC gaming controller, so I have no idea what the difference in playability between the two formats are.

Set in a space war of in the far future you play as a pilot of the experimental combat unit called Strike Suit Zero. This small indie game is something of a homage to space combat simulator games of the 90’s like Colony Wars, Descent, and Freelancer. But be warned its not all just pretty graphics and cool effects. To play this game and be actually good, it takes twitch like reflexes and good split-second judgment.
just awesome :D

I have no idea why the metascore is only 65/100. It would be your average spaceshooter, flying around dogfighting, homing missiles, perhaps powerful nonhoming too, stuff like that. BUT THE STRIKE SUIT!!! You have a transforming fighter, which includes autotargeting and multitargeting missile barrages. It is a LONG time since you ever had this much fun trashing enemies in any 3rd person game! Soundtrack is awesome too, not your average techno stuff, but more like an ambient easy tones that fits the size of space
Great game couldn't get enough of it. Playing always reminded me of Gundam Seed. Only problem was it's not longer.
This game is fun, rather difficult, and has very tight gameplay.  Give it a shot if you find it on sale, and need something to scratch that space combat itch until Star Citizen comes out.
Any self respecting Mecha or Gundam fan should play this, fast, furious space combat and never a slow moment. It also looks gorgeous!!!

If you grew up with Gundam then this is the game for you. It's a great game that's worth every penny.\n\nThe only downside is that if your computer isn't up to par with the game's standards, it will lag. The flight mechanics are simple and clean, and easy enough to learn. While it does take time to master, you have plenty of missions to learn.

This game is absolutely enjoyable. If you loved space shooters and ♥♥♥♥ like that, you'll like this game. You have a variety of ships and missions that have various degrees of difficulty. Once you get the shape-shifting mech/fighter you'll be in the meat and potatoes.\n\nTrust me when I saw read the controls and learn how the game works. Flying balls deep into a carrier ship formation before shifting into a huge gun platform mecha and launching 100 anime missles is an amazing feeling.

An inteligent, fast, smooth, and unfailingly beautiful game.  The game is small for the sheer enjoyment it brings, and with the Mega Bundle coming wth the full soundtrack and a kick-♥♥♥ artbook, it's what I recommend to buy.  This game is an excelent sci-fi experience in a rich and well rendered universe, the characters are distinguished but not obtrusive, letting the game speak for itself, and boy does it.  Enemies are inovative when given the chance to be, and showing any weakness will result on them mercilessly pursuing you.  Not to mention the incredibly active and powerful capital ships that power through space as you dart around every nook and cranny chasing enemy fighter craft away from your ship's critical systems and opening enemy ships up for attack.\nChase and dogfight your way through swarms of enemy fighters, then switch to 'Strike Suit Mode' and completely erradicate the lot.\nI recommend this for any space combat fan, even if dogfights aren't your thing, the vistas, music, and watching massive ships slug it out around you is well worth the price.

I really enjoyed this game. Some of the main criticisms were with the control scheme and with the length of the game. Personally I got used to the controls quickly on keyboard and mouse, and if you have a controller they are supposedly better. They are also very customisable if you don't like the default system. As for the length, the game has a lot to offer for its price in my opinion, and at a reduced price you can't complain! Missions are a good length (though the checkpoint system can be rather punishing on harder missions) and it is an arcade style game in the sense that you get points for everything so replaying missions for platinum medals is encouraged.

The other main criticism was that it wasn't enough like some other space flight game that the reviewer liked. Personally I don't see how this is a valid criticism for a reviewer to make who is supposed to be reviewing this game and not one that is over ten years old. This is its own game, go watch some gameplay if you are undecided, don't presume it will be like x-wing because thats what you want it to be like, you may be dissapointed.

If you like bright flashy space combat and a game that rewards players that learn the mechanics and uses them instead of expecting it to be like that space game you played in 98 then pick it up!

Seriously one of the better games from the Humble Bundle X. A great single player experience. The style reminds me a lot of X-Wing vs Tie Fighter as well as the game Oil Rush from a previous Humble Bundle.
If you're not one for story much, then this is a fun, balls to the wall, space shooter.  The graphics give it a bit of a Homeworld 2 feel, in a good way.

Overall a good game, sadly not -great- due to quite a few things, but a worthy homage to titles such as Omegaboost and Macross.

Goods:
-Very nice graphics and design.
-SOLID game play (Extreamly challanging even on Easy, yet satisfying when pulling off major kills/actions)
-Missions are lengthy and mostly fulfilling in terms of mission content.
-Controls (for a gamepad/xbox controller) are satisfying once you get use to them.

Bads:
-Game is BRUTAL frequently if you don't know what to do. Higher difficulties are painfuly hard and usually discourage further playing.
-Game is short overall, even with buying DLC. (DLC isn't worth buying unless on sale)
-Achievements are hard to obtain for some missions (further discouraging play).
-EASY to get lost within missions due to their vast size, hard (often impossible) to tell 'up' from 'down'.

Other:
-Voice acting could be better.
-Game could greatly benefit more ingame (outside of mission) content (ex: ingame model viewer)
-Could use better camera options.
-Could use better oriented DLC (ex: a strike suit that has higher performance for more diffictult situations)
-Could use better story eliments and detail.
-Would GREATLY benefit if a Free Mode" was added (ex: free flight to just fly around
date: no objectives)\n-Multiplayer CO-OP would GREATLY help with difficult gameplay plus VS. Mode would add more content."

IF this was the studios first project, I am really excited to see what they do next.  For a kickstarter project, this game is really polished.  The controls feel really good once you get used to them.  I am playing with a 360 controller for PC and now I wish that all my old experiences with space sims were with this type of controller.  The dual joysticks really work well for giving you yaw.  I really like that they have different ship types and didn't focus exclusively on the Strike Suit.  Playing the Bomber or Interceptor was really enjoyable and added more variety and depth to the missions.  It was kind of nice that they control how much time you can spend in the mecha form, but I think if they would of balanced that form better, there wouldn't of been the need.  I just have a hard time with it being a sci-fi genre and them saying you need to charge the suit by shooting stuff.  Why not just have it be a thermal cool down thing or something.

The story isn't overly exciting, the main character is just a name, although they are trying to manufacture a bit of a story with him.  The story doesn't add too much depth to the game, other than serving as a minimal segway to different types of missions.  But the gameplay is really fun, and the graphics are really beautiful.  It feels really amazing when you barrel role over to the underside of a capital ship after making a turret run over the top.  It really feels like you are playing in one of the epic sci fi movie battles.  I don't think I have had a game get this right before.

If you are into the space combat sim genre, check it out.  The mech suit transformation is what this game brings to the table, along with updated controls, graphics and sound.  It makes me wish these guys had a license to redo wing commmander or tie fighter, they just need a few new writers.

A nice refresh of the space combat genre that delivers an incredibly thrilling and fast-paced combat experience.

Strike Suit Zero is indeed reminiscent of FreeSpace 2, but the addition of the ability to transform into a nimble space mech adds a whole new dimension to the experience. The game’s controls proved to be highly intuitive; it’s relatively easy to pick up, and the ships (be it fighter or mech) were an absolute joy to pilot. Once the Strike Suit is acquired, much of the challenge revolves around the careful management of flux energy, which is replenished upon successful kills, and expended when utilizing the high-powered weapons in strike mode. The story does an adequate job of tying the missions together, and even has a sufficiently interesting twist at the end. As to be expected from the genre, combat is potentially repetitive, but the game mitigates the problem by intensifying the challenge significantly as the campaign progresses, with enemy attacks becoming ever more relentless.

The game's balance does leave something to be desired however, especially with regard to its roster of ships. Once the titular Strike Suit is made available, there's little in the way of incentives to warrant the selection of other ships. Furthermore, only generic information is provided on unlocked weapons and ship upgrades (granted upon completing mission-specific challenges). Without stat-related information, most of the weapons unlocked over the course of the campaign seem pointless. i.e. It's hard to justify the choice of heavier weapons when they incur penalties (like reduced projectile velocity) without delivering a discernible difference in dps.

Graphics-wise, there's nothing revolutionary here. Nevertheless, it is a step forward as far as space combat sims are concerned. The game maintains a pleasantly minimalist (if somewhat Tron-esque) aesthetic. Each faction's vessels feature sufficiently distinctive designs with a good balance of details, and a number of missions are set against surprisingly breath-taking planetary backdrops. The bloom lighting effects can get over-the-top at times, but on the whole it fits the game well. If I were to nit-pick, some of the shortcomings would be:
- completely static HUD portraits
- inconsistent attention to detail: absurdly, some large objects like comms relays and shield generators attached to installations disappear without leaving any wreckage when destroyed

The game isn't perfect, but I personally find that it brings enough to the table to be a worthy addition to the genre. If you've been on the hunt for a new space combat simulator, this is one heck of an exhilarating ride that you wouldn't want to miss.

Very enjoyable, especially considering that it was another inde kickstarter funded game.  Heard some people mention that they found it boring after a while, but I enjoyed every minute of it.  The game itself is stunning both in the visual and audio department.  The movement and reactions are all very fluid, the enviorements look awesome, and the visuals are just very satisfying in general.  Having your vision whited out from fighter explosions is always a cool effect.  The soundtrack sounds professionally done, the main song features KOKIA who has done vocals for other video games and anime series.  Sound effects are also very well done, and make destroying things in your transforming machine of death all that much more fun.
The story wasn't exactly anything special, but it sufficed.  I'd say that was one of its few lacking points.  It ran on max settings perfectly fine except for one point in the story where there were literally things exploding EVERYWHERE, and it started to get bogged down, otherwise it was fine.
Very happy I picked up this game, would be awesome to see a more developed sequel come out eventually, as it would be a shame for such a great concept platform stop here.

Edit: Just figured I'd mention it took me about 10 hours to finish.  Not sure if any of that was the game sitting open during breaks, but I'd say at least 8.5 of those hours were in game blowing ♥♥♥♥ up.  Did take me a couple of tries to get past some checkpoints.

Otherwise, I would recommend this game and the Arcade Mode like version, Strike Suit Inifinite.

First of all: This ain't a game for anyone. You absolutely NEED a gamepad/joystick and some gaming experience because this game requires some ability to be able to effectively play it.

That being said, I can continue now with my considerations about the game:
I've grown in a generation with lots of fantasy and mistery around intergalactic dogfights with Starwars, Starfox, Gundam, Battlestar Galactica, etc etc. and as a game I've set a minimum mark for every game that featured dogfights + space: Starfox 64 (the DS one is good, but not THAT good).
Since then, I believe, I've lived in a limbo. There's been, of course some games that filled some of that gap like BF3 with it's cool dogfight, but nothing like that.
Well, you may fire at me as many apples as you want but, for me, this game has set another mark for spaceship dogfight.
It's more deep, more consistent, more beautiful, more realistic (control and weaponwise) and it has a playable gundam.

Now to the game's basics:
This game is about control. You need to understand and get used to it. It can be hard and punishing first, but after you get the hang of it, it'll all start to feel right and interesting. The story of the Strike Suit Zero is about a fight between Earth and it's colonies and you play the pilot of a new prototype fighter developed by the earthlings: the Strike Suit, a Fighter that can take the form of a Gundam for a limited time. Before the missions take place, you can (and it is recomended to) customize your weaponry according to your ship capacity (the standard strike suit has 2 slots for machine guns and 2 for missiles).
The game counts with a good voice acting (but not as deep and engaging as of the Starfox's) and during the mission you'll hear a lot of conversation to keep you informed of what's happening and what you have to do and you're pretty much free to do anything (knowing that by doing anything but the mission's goal may fail the mission :P) and fly anywhere, vertically, horizontally, etc.
The game is very dynamic and you'll often find yourself in a situation that you'll have to be aware of many factors (e.g: torpedoes being fired at your capital ship, fighters on your tail, enemy capital ships firing at you, mission targets, missiles being fired at you, etc etc... all at the same ♥♥♥♥ing time) and that may be a little difficult for people who aren't used to this type of game.

The good:
SSZ can be a little punishing for mistakes and that's good, I miss that in games. I miss that sometimes, decisions need to be made and you need to be cautious about your actions (at the same time that you need to be fast while you make your decision; The game is gorgeous, you'll often find yourself more focused into looking at the scene than on your objective; It let's you deal with situations creatively and I mean it. It's not the false creative (as in Trine), you'll actually end up having to formulate some sort of plan of action on a mission after you've failed a few times (even more if you're aiming for mission achievments which rewards you with a ship upgrade); The creators of the game said they have plenty of content ahead of us which will keep the game running (still waiting for multiplayer co-op); Not so dumb AI. Look, the AI isn't good, but I've seen worse and it can, sometimes, challenge you, so, for now, that's good enough.

The bad:
You'll have to pay for replayability. The game has no replay (unless you count achievment as scorehunting as replayability). To work this problem around the devs launched Strike Suit Infinity which costs almost half the original game's price and that's, uhh, not fair; The Strike Mode needs some tweaking, because while it has the function to lock-on multiple targets for your missile barrage, you'll end up in a situation where you try to lock an enemy and the game won't let you; The AI is dumb, at least dumb enought to let you shoot them down without little reaction. You'll face 2 kinds of AI in the game: The Elite and the commoner"

reviewText: Welcome to a game of frustration and balls all in your face. This is a game where left is right right is forward up is backwards and down is still down.... You will most likely spend the first several missions screaming at your PC while debating if you should go sit in a corner and cry. A game where you and your NPC buddies must fight insane amounts of bad dudes only to have your NPC buddies sit in the back diddling each other while the enemies forces themself on you. For some people this could be fun, for others is a nightmarish PTSD flash back in a can waiting for you to open you eyes so it can punch you in the face and spit on your mother.\n\nOk so it gets better... but really its like prison sex, it gets better after a while.
Fun and addictive. Think Zone of The Enders meets Homeworld. Only 13 missions with rewards for repeating for better scores, bargain for < £4 on sale though.
Very good space fight sim game. Makes me think of a more colorful, modern, tie-fighter-like, game.

If you want a deeply strategic, thinking mans space sim ... then this game is not for you. However if you want raw escapism, over-powered mecha delight, then step right up.\nThis game is visually stunning, has great music, an easy learning curve, and is just outright fun!\nStrap into your Stike Suit and go go go!

A long time ago, in a galaxy far, far away, there was FreeSpace2. This Space Combat Sim became arguably the best in the genre. Sadly, when FS2 came out in 1999 the Space Combat Sim genre was slowly dying. It was the last of an era and no others that came after could hold a candle to it. I played thousands of hours on FreeSpace 2 and the various fan made mods for over a decade, all the while wishing for someone to come revive the genre with a game worthy of FS2's legacy. And it wasn't until 2013 that my wish came true with the release of STRIKE SUIT ZERO.

STRIKE SUIT ZERO -
CONTROLS -- The game gives Space Sim enthusiasts the ship control they crave while giving the casual player easy mouse control. After the first mission I was digging around in my closet for my old Saitek x36 Flight controller. Mapping controls was easy enough, but be careful if your rudder is messed up. Axis Z is hard coded to menu navigation and could make mission and craft selection a pain. I would hightly suggest turning up your X/Y Axis sensitivity as the default setting makes your fighter move like an overloaded freighter.

GAMEPLAY -- The missions feel like those from FreeSpace, my meaning being your not the focus of the fight. Epic battles are being waged around you. You are only a small cog in the machine, as it should be. You have specific objectives assigned to you while other units perform their duties. There are only four ships to chose from in SST, but I did not find the selection lacking. They were easy to customize to my flight style though the use of weapon load-outs (which remind me of the load-outs you could pick in Freespace, just with fewer choices). SST adds its own interesting twist to the genre with the Strike Suit"
date: a craft that has the ability to transform into a mech like something out of an anime. At first I thought this was going to be a cheesy gimmick-like easy button
recommended: but I was pleasantly surprised. The strike suit mode was not overly powered and did require a decent amount of skill to use effectively. You have to charge the strike suit though "FLUX"
hoursPlayed: which can be gained by dishing out damage or less so though damage received. Your weapons in Strike Mode use up FLUX and once it is used up your ship is reverted back to interceptor mode.\n\nCONS: The game is woefully short. I would have liked to see multiple campaigns and possibly a co-op mode. Also
voteText: you have no control over your wing-men. In my honest opinion that would have made the game better for me. However
helpfulPercent: this is just nit-picking. The game is awesome.\n\nAnyone who has played FS2
votesHelpful: I highly suggest this game to you. When Born Ready boasts that SSZ is "Space Combat. Reborn" they are not just talking out their ♥♥♥. They delivered on that promise. Check it out."

JIST: It's basically colony wars (PSX) + Freelancer, but with no depth. The missions toward the end were frantic and quite enjoyable, but it takes too long to get to that point. There is replay value here, but I feel that playing the entire thing over again may not be a priority for me.

GRAPHICS: Not as great as the marketing suggests. The texture quality and models look a tad dated, and do not have the detail that I was expecting. The sky domes however are very nice to look at, but there is nothing revolutionary or impressive here.

GAMEPLAY: The game has solid mechanics, and controls. From K+M, controller, and joystick they all work wonderfully. The only issue I have here is that with this control style you cannot make percise movements very easily.

STORY: This is not the main attraction of the game, and it's fairly bare bones.

VALUE: I purchased this @ $15. And I'd say it was worth this much

This is a game that tries to continue a strong, and lately forgotten, pedigree which includes the likes of Wing Commander and FreeSpace.

Dogfighting does bring memories of those classic games, and coupled with some very impressive visuals that borrow a bit from Homeworld (fused with some Japanese aesthetics) and a great soundtrack, it's a very strong offering.

The game is unforgiving. Really, really unforgiving. The difficulty curve suddenly spikes upwards and in the end you are required to not hesitate at all in your decisions. You 'must' be able to achieve that zen-like state of mind to overcome the final levels, and if you're like me, the kind of person that completely loves that...

...then there is no other quite like it.
Great looking space shooter where you can transform from a space ship to a mech. However my favourite part is just looking around at the trully beautiful space.

Like the IGN review below, it IS a unique blend of arcade combat mechanics with good ole' fashion space combat simulation movement. The graphics are lovely, and the soundtrack is like something out of Ghost in the Shell ( a quintessential cyberpunk anime). The difficulty spikes greatly within two missions, and the battles can be very frantic to the point of being distracted by EVERYTHING on screen. The game has some replay value, and allows you to use unlocked strike suits/ships on previous missions, as well as leaderdoards for each mssion.

Unfortunately, it lacks a multiplayer, but the developers aren't ruling out a multiplayer function in the future, as well as an SDK for mods.


A definite buy for space combat/mecha junkies, but if you want multiplayer, you might have to wait a bit.

If your looking for a decent dogfighting game for fun this game is exhilirating except for the last mission. I found the controls a bit clunky but aside from that the only thing that continually frustrated me was the inability for me to lock on to the specific target I wanted. The brief in game explination hardly covers the use of the system adequately and knowing where those torpedos are when the entire screen is filled with explosions is quite difficult at times. All that aside I would recommend this game but wait and get it on sale. It is not a $20.00 tittle I feel it missed out on much needed development such as character development, story depth, and scenario design. Unlike what I've seen from the rest of the reviews I had no issues with the checkpoint system incorperated they were well placed and the entire point was to make sure you werent just throwing out a million rockets willy nilly so you would have the required resources to beat the end of a mission segment and reach the begining of another checkpoint. All in all the checkpoints did not hamper me in fact they were an asset once I figured out how they were placed and I knew when it was okay to waste what I had to make it to the next checkpoint after which it was acceptable to die and get more special weapon ammo and armor.
I haven't played a lot of this but the bit that I have was amazing.  it actaully reminds me of x-wing and tie figter from the old IBM 100% PC Compatible days

reviewText: Strike Suit Zero is influenced heavily by the classics. The ship design takes inspiration from Macross, Homeworld and Gundam, and the gameplay borrows elements from Freespace, Wing Commander and the X-Wing series. It makes a solid attempt at reintroducing what seems to be a lost genre, then makes an even bolder attempt at  adding to it. This is definitely a game for  fans of the aforementioned titles, and is highly recommended as a foreword for anyone who were to explore the mecha or space combat genres.

Targeting is very difficult for two reasons: 1) everything is red (crossharis, enemy ships, background) which makes it very difficult to see what you're actually doing, and there's no ability to change the color of your HUD.  2) cannot cycle through targets, you can only target the closest enemy and what your crosshairs fall on.  In a game of high technology these are some pretty big holes which make what should be a fun game pretty annoying.

This game is awesome. It's a confusing 3-D bullet hell of a grind fest, but for once I'm happy to go back and grind in a game because it's so much fun. Also the grinding time gave me enough time for the subtle plot to finally sink in to my head. By the start I was confusedly and awkwardly floating around space in a clunky machine and at the end I was a master of space in a mech suit that shoots interstellar death torpedoes at hundreds of disposable enemies.\nAlso, the conclusion of the game caught me way off-guard.\nIf you like a) Being a mech b) Being in space or c) Playing Starfox 64 over and over to get the medals on every planet, this game is your messiah.

If your looking for a decent dogfighting game for fun this game is exhilirating except for the last mission. I found the controls a bit clunky but aside from that the only thing that continually frustrated me was the inability for me to lock on to the specific target I wanted. The brief in game explination hardly covers the use of the system adequately and knowing where those torpedos are when the entire screen is filled with explosions is quite difficult at times. All that aside I would recommend this game but wait and get it on sale. It is not a $20.00 tittle I feel it missed out on much needed development such as character development, story depth, and scenario design. Unlike what I've seen from the rest of the reviews I had no issues with the checkpoint system incorperated they were well placed and the entire point was to make sure you werent just throwing out a million rockets willy nilly so you would have the required resources to beat the end of a mission segment and reach the begining of another checkpoint. All in all the checkpoints did not hamper me in fact they were an asset once I figured out how they were placed and I knew when it was okay to waste what I had to make it to the next checkpoint after which it was acceptable to die and get more special weapon ammo and armor.

Strike Suit Zero is a very unique game. It's offers a level of immersion that other space opera games lack. This is a heavy action-oriented game and the story is not merely a vehicle.  Controls are not complex and only several keys are required and the game doesn't dump a rediculous ammount on you, forcing you to stretch your hand all accross your keyboard. The plot is not pointless too. It will fool you into thinking it's a total linear story line. So SPOILER ALERT: at the very end you have a choice.

Combat is very satisfying. Ships are graceful, fair, and not clunky to handle. Controls are simple, easy to operate, and convenient. The story surprised me as stated above.

A game from a tiny developer with a successful kickstarter project, Strike Suit Zero is an accomplishment I'm sure many will remember. What this game lacks in complexity, it more than makes up for elsewhere. If anything, all you can really complain about is that it feels as though there's just not enough of it!

So you want to know what this game is, what it does, etc. Well, imagine for one moment if the RTS game Homeworld, was smooshed together with the TV series Battlestar Galactica, the pacing of Super R-Type, the mecha styling of Mobile Suit Gundam, the atmosphere and vibrance of Zone of the Enders and infused with the soul of the X3 series. Now imagine that all of that comes together in an orgy of frenetic 3d-space combat, beautiful, vibrant graphics, a challenging AI, a good selection of ships/mecha and weapons and a soundtrack reminiscent of the musical stylings of Talvin Singh.

Bottom Line : If you love your twitch gaming, but also want an atmospheric, challenging, not to mention stunning, 3d space shooter with an engaging story and an AI that'll keep you on your toes, then look no further. This really is a gem, and at under a fiver on steam, you've really got no excuses if this kind of thing is your cup of tea!

This isn't all bad though, as it makes you more careful and not just recklessly charging into 20 enemy ships just to see if it works.

Varied optional objectives that unlock ship upgrades are also present. These are really fun to go for an are appropriately rewarding if you complete them.

Solid mechanics and really great gameplay. This whole game comes together and it’s simply a great work of art. Dog fights, strike mode, blasting capital ships, and getting high scores. Doing this and having a blast is what it’s all about. This fills the void of my desire for Ace Combat for PCs (I’m talking about a good Ace Combat mind you).\n\nStrike Suit Zero is entirely a campaign. The story itself isn’t stellar, but makes the combat feel real and each mission has some weight to it. There’s a great sense of an epic fight when you’re in the midst of a fight between capital class ships and hoards of fighters. As a player you aren’t some overpowered-one-ship-destroy-everything-and-do-anything since you have to rely on your allies to help fill the void in your weaknesses. On the flip side you can greatly assist your allies by targeting specific objectives and hitting the enemy where it really hurts. Probably a great example is if your capital ship is in danger from enemy beam cannons you can snipe out the beam cannons on the enemy capital ships. Another good one is sniping out AA turrets on capital ships so your bombers can take them out quickly and safely. The campaign does a nice job of mixing up what you need to do so it’s never a stale series of mission.

reviewText: Interesting concept and very nice graphics. There is a level of strategy as well, for instance, when in capital ship battles, taking out various hardpoints on larger ships to give your fleet an advantage and so forth. My only complaint is the clumsy controls, especially for keyboard & mouse. Somewhat difficult for accurate fire that is often necessary in dogfights, and Strike Suit controls take some getting used to, since you're constantly switching between fighter and SS modes. Overall the game is enjoyable, a pleasant remenisce of the Macross series.
